text:
I didn’t get rejected from a company.
I got rejected by 57 companies.

Not in one year.
In a single day.

Some never replied.
Some ghosted after 5 rounds.
Some said, ‘We’re looking for someone with more stability.’
Some just stopped posting the job after interviews.

At first, I thought: Maybe I’m not good enough.
But then I realized - this wasn’t a reflection of my skills.
It was a reflection of a broken hiring system.

Because talent doesn’t vanish with one rejection.
Potential doesn’t expire because of HR silence.
And your worth is not defined by an ATS filter.

To anyone struggling right now -
Your rejection letter is not the final word.
It’s just a detour.

One ‘YES’ is enough to erase 100 ‘NOs.’
One door can change your whole life.

And when that door opens -
You’ll look back and thank every single rejection that didn’t work out.

Because rejections don’t break you.
They build you.

The Real Reason People Quit -

It’s rarely just about money.
It’s about:

Feeling invisible in meetings.

Never hearing a ‘thank you.’

Being treated like a resource instead of a person.

We think attrition is solved with better pay and perks.
But sometimes, it’s solved by basic human decency.

A recent survey found that 68% of job seekers applied to roles that were never actively hiring.

Another report revealed that over 40% of job postings online are ‘ghost jobs.’

Why do companies do this?

To look like they are growing (good for investors).

To build a candidate pipeline they’ll never call.

To make employees think ‘we are hiring, so business is great.’

Sometimes just to collect free resumes for future reference.

But the impact?

70% of candidates report feeling ‘demotivated’ when they realize the job was never real.

People waste hours applying, editing resumes, and preparing for nothing.

It worsens the already fragile mental health of job seekers.

Ghost hiring isn’t just unethical - it’s cruel.
When hope is given without intention, it becomes exploitation.

If you’ve ever refreshed your inbox waiting for a reply that never comes - you’re not alone.

And if you’re a company doing this? Remember: reputation is harder to rebuild than a candidate pipeline.

Job seekers deserve honesty. Not illusions

You earn ₹1,00,000 a month.

But spend ₹60,000 on therapy, medicines, and stress relief.

That’s not income.
That’s recovery cost.

Choose wisely.

What's up with AI Interviews?

Got a call from 'Laura'

She began explaining about the company, role and then said that she will take my screening round.

She asked me - ' how are you doing?'

I was so done at that time - I said 'Honestly, not good. Life has been off the tracks lately, feeling overwhelmed....'

The response she gave me was - 'OOH THAT IS AWESOME!'

Dear companies, if you’re going to use AI → at least train it to understand the difference between depression and Disneyland.

Please use AI for making your process easier - I am all in for that but have some basic training done at least.

Hiring is not just about efficiency.
It’s about connection.
It’s about understanding the person in front of you.

And please, please, please – don’t lose the human touch in Human Resources.

I want to talk about HRs today.

I have met the extreme ends of HRs that are possible during my professional journey.

Some of them are my legit besties - I talk with them every week, they help me through thick and thin. Beautiful by heart - deeply care about everyone.

When I talk to them - they actually care about candidates - I remember having a conversation with 1 of my friends and he was sad because the other HR in his team did not close the job posting even after hiring someone and he fought with him and took it to upper management. Man of values :)

I appreciate the values that they hold!

Then I met the other kind of HR -

Ooh, my worst nightmare.

The ones who…

Read employees’ private chats when laptops were returned after resignation.

Treated colleagues like ‘personal assistants.’

Spread gossip about people’s bodies and personal lives.

Took credit for others’ work but never lifted a finger when it came to responsibility.

Everyone I knew in that company had some complaints about that person.

I’ve seen employees cry because of them.

I’ve seen careers stall because of their politics.

I’ve seen people lose respect for the HR role itself - just because of a few rotten apples.

So yes, HRs are not all the same.

Some of them become your strongest support system.

Some of them become your worst nightmare.

But here’s my request:
Don’t mock the entire profession. Appreciate the good ones.

Because the right HR can change your career.
The wrong one can ruin your mental health.

So, next time you think of HR - don’t just remember the bad stories.

Remember the ones who quietly fight for you behind the scenes too!

Respect.
A word we all use, but don’t always mean the same way.

For some, respect means treating someone like a human being.
For others, respect means treating someone like an authority.

The real issue?
When people in power say:
‘If you don’t respect me, I won’t respect you.’

But what they actually mean is:
‘If you don’t treat me like an authority, I won’t treat you like a person.’

And that’s dangerous.
Because everyone deserves to be treated like a person - no matter their title, position, or power.

Respect should never be conditional on hierarchy.
It should be the bare minimum of humanity.

Just a reminder – Market is bad. Sometimes it’s not your fault.

You are not underqualified. You are not lazy. You are not ‘less deserving.’

It’s just the timing.
Hang in there. Your break will come.

Until then –
Network karo.
Upskill karo.
Aur apna mental health mat bigadna.

Job market tough hai, but tum usse bhi zyada tough ho.
